This
On
Week
List
Fiction
ANGELS & DEMONS, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A Harvard scholar tries to save the Vatican from the machinations of an underground society.
THE GUARDIAN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $7.50.) While trying to choose between two suitors, a young widow realizes that her life is in danger.
THE SHERBROOKE TWINS, by Catherine Coulter. (Jove, $7.99.) The adventures, romantic and otherwise, of 19th-century English brothers.
THE MORNING AFTER, by Lisa Jackson. (Zebra, $6.99.) A journalist in Savannah finds herself being drawn into a deadly game played by a serial killer.
DECEPTION POINT, by Dan Brown. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) An intelligence analyst is sent to the Arctic on a special assignment by the White House.
LOST LIGHT, by Michael Connelly. (Warner Vision, $7.99.) The former Los Angeles homicide detective Harry Bosch unofficially reopens a cold case involving a 24-year-old woman who was strangled.
DEAD AIM, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $7.99.) On assignment in Colorado, a photojournalist is pursued by killers after she discovers a conspiracy.
DIGITAL FORTRESS, by Dan Brown. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $14.95 and $7.99.) A cryptographer at the N.S.A. becomes enmeshed in murderous political intrigue after she breaks a mysterious code.
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Dell, $7.99.) A public defender in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy involving one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in the world.
THE SECRET LIFE OF BEES, by Sue Monk Kidd. (Penguin, $14.) In South Carolina in 1964, a teenage girl tries to discover the secret to her mother's past.
THE PERFECT LOVER, by Stephanie Laurens. (Avon, $6.99.) In 19th-century England, a wealthy roué and a rich woman decide that the time has come to get married.
*LIFE OF PI, by Yann Martel. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) An allegory on the high seas, in which a teenage boy and a tiger are thrown together in a lifeboat.
ONE HUNDRED YEARS OF SOLITUDE, by Gabriel García Márquez. (Perennial Classics, $14.) The magic realist novel, first published in 1967, about the Buendía family and the mythical town of Macondo.
THE FOOTPRINTS OF GOD, by Greg Iles. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) Fleeing the lab where he works, a man must outwit the sinister supercomputer being built there, which threatens to destroy the world.
DATING GAME, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $7.99.) After her husband leaves her, a 46-year-old woman decides what to do with the rest of her life.

This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) A memoir of a teacher's life in Iran, centered on her reading group.

THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $14.95.) The tale of a great architect (Daniel Hudson Burnham) and a serial killer (H. H. Holmes), who were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Broadway, $11.95.) The author tells of his visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
TOUCHING THE VOID, by Joe Simpson. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) A mountain climber describes a disastrous accident in 1985.
SEX AND THE CITY: Kiss and tell, by Amy Sohn. Additional text by Sarah Wildman. (Melcher Media/HBO/Pocket Books, $20.) A revised edition of a companion volume to the television series.
HOLY BLOOD, HOLY GRAIL, by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh and Henry Lincoln. (Delta, $15; Dell, $7.99.) Extraordinary conclusions about Christ.
*BRINGING DOWN THE HOUSE, by Ben Mezrich. (Free Press, $14.) How six M.I.T. students won more than $3 million at Las Vegas casinos.
LET FREEDOM RING, by Sean Hannity. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $14.95.) The commentator surveys domestic and foreign issues after Sept. 11.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
RUNNING WITH SCISSORS, by Augusten Burroughs. (Picador, $14.) A memoir of a psychiatrist who went crazy while the author was in his care.
ABRAHAM, by Bruce Feiler. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) Judaism, Christianity and Islam as seen through the story of one man.
THE SAVAGE NATION, by Michael Savage. (Plume, $14.) A radio talk show host proposes to save America from liberalism.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' '' recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Ballantine, $15.95 and $7.99.) The story of the horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
*FAST FOOD NATION, by Eric Schlosser. (Peren-nial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A survey of ''the dark side of the all-American meal.''
*MICHELANGELO & THE POPE'S CEILING, by Ross King. (Penguin, $15.) The painting of the Sistine Chapel's ceiling and the circumstances surrounding it.

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
THE PURPOSE-DRIVEN LIFE, by Rick Warren. (Zondervan, $19.99.) Finding the meaning of life through God. (+)
THE SOUTH BEACH DIET, by Arthur Agatston. (Rodale, $24.95.) A weight-loss plan designed by a Miami cardiologist. (+)
THE SEXY YEARS, by Suzanne Somers. (Crown, $25.) Tips on how to have ''a fabulous sex life'' and achieve ''endless vitality.''
THE ULTIMATE WEIGHT SOLUTION, by Phil McGraw. (Free Press, $26.) Dr. Phil identifies ''seven keys'' to losing weight.
THE POWER OF INTENTION, by Wayne W. Dyer. (Hay House, $24.95.) Ways to find spiritual solutions to life's problems.

List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Quill, $13.95; Avon, $7.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
1,000 PLACES TO SEE BEFORE YOU DIE, by Patricia Schultz. (Workman, $18.95.) A reference book for travelers.
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Heidi Murkoff, Arlene Eisenberg and Sandee Hathaway. (Workman, $13.95.) For parents-to-be. (+)
THE ATKINS ESSENTIALS, by Atkins Health and Medical Information Services. (Avon, $7.50.) A two-week program for starting the diet. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 13, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
